definition: A nerve cell; the basic building block of the nervous system responsible for transmitting information through electrical and chemical signals.
Supporting cells in the nervous system that provide structure, nutrition, and insulation to neurons.
Consists of the brain and spinal cord; integrates sensory information and coordinates body functions.
Composed of nerves outside the CNS, including sensory and motor divisions that connect the CNS to limbs and organs.
Afferent neurons that carry sensory information from receptors to the CNS.
Efferent neurons that carry impulses from the CNS to effectors like muscles and glands.
Neurons that relay signals between sensory and motor neurons within the CNS.
A junction where information is transmitted from one neuron to another or to an effector cell.
Chemical messenger that transmits signals across a synapse from one neuron to a target cell.
The voltage difference across the neuron membrane at rest, typically around -70 mV.
A rapid change in electrical charge across the neuron's membrane, allowing the transmission of a signal.
The long extension of a neuron that transmits impulses away from the cell body to other cells.
Branches of a neuron that receive messages from other neurons and conduct impulses toward the cell body.
Fatty substance that insulates axons, speeding up nerve impulses.
Gaps in the myelin sheath of axons where action potentials are regenerated, enabling saltatory conduction.
Rapid transmission of a nerve impulse along a myelinated axon, jumping from one node of Ranvier to the next.
Star-shaped glial cell in the CNS that supports neurons and helps form the blood-brain barrier.
Glial cell in the CNS that produces myelin for axons.
Glial cell in the PNS that produces myelin around axons, aiding in nerve regeneration.
Small glial cells in the CNS that act as immune cells, removing debris and pathogens.
Glial cells lining the ventricles of the brain and central canal of the spinal cord, involved in producing cerebrospinal fluid.
Condition where there is a difference in electrical charge between the inside and outside of a cell membrane.
Process where the neuron's membrane potential becomes less negative, moving closer to zero.
When the membrane potential becomes more negative than the resting potential.
Period following an action potential when a neuron cannot initiate another action potential.
Time during which no action potential can be initiated, regardless of the stimulus strength.
Time during which a stronger than normal stimulus is needed to elicit an action potential.
A postsynaptic potential that depolarizes the neuron, making it more likely to fire an action potential.
A postsynaptic potential that hyperpolarizes the neuron, making it less likely to fire an action potential.
A neurotransmitter involved in muscle contraction and autonomic functions.
A neurotransmitter involved in reward, motivation, and motor control; associated with Parkinson's disease.
A neurotransmitter involved in mood regulation, sleep, and appetite.
A selective barrier formed by astrocytes that protects the CNS from harmful substances in the blood.
Process where multiple neurons synapse onto a single neuron, allowing it to integrate information.
Process where a single neuron synapses onto multiple neurons, allowing one signal to reach multiple targets.
When repeated stimulation makes a neuron more responsive to subsequent stimulation.
Groups of interconnected neurons in the CNS that process information together for specific functions.
A cluster of neuron cell bodies in the peripheral nervous system.
The gap between neurons at a synapse across which neurotransmitters are transmitted.
A neurotransmitter involved in arousal, alertness, and the fight-or-flight response.
A neurotransmitter involved in transmitting pain signals in the nervous system.
Neurotransmitters that act as natural painkillers and mood enhancers.
